run.lit: basically, we are pretty close to something that can actually be useful

think about what it was like to try and teach yourself from a video and also how you've taught other people things. The pause points are extremely useful and you spend a lot of time looking at at the screen trying to parse individual movements
Think about the double broadsword flower and how joy tried to learn it
think about teaching danni the intermediate set
think about trying to teach yourself form the prototype on monday
think about coaching badminton
Notes:
-Pause points are important
-you need that slight pause to get started before the move plays-
-times are not as important, you watch the videos to make sure the moves are right
- you move from having watched a move to wanting to learn the next move
- you don't know which parts of the move are important until you have tried it a bit first - make editing a move easier and adding pause points
- you are talking to somebody who teaches you the moves "go forward, go back" etc. IF you could just talk to the app that would be absolutely amazing
- if you have the arrow keys, there's no point in having the entire bar for random ass controls, that can be moved or shrunk
but they should still be there, i think...
- Distinguish free mode, which is just playing the video, with edit move mode and play move mode. Play move mode should cut focus onto the move
- Nvm. It just needs to be very clear when a move is being played

task.title: rethink entire flow, now that you've seen what needs to be done

run.lit: make sure all actions are explicit, saving, canceling, playing, etc.
- pretty important and nice idea, that once you are done with one move you can move on and learn the next.
Learning so far happens a move at a time. Learn a move, learn the next few moves. Then maybe go back and review them all together
